deals.pitchHtml:
As the old Irish saying goes, “Your feet will bring you to where your heart is.” Your appetite is likely to be there, too. Step on into Middleton's on Main with this offer, good for $30 worth of food with an authentic Irish flair, yours for only $15.

Get your smiling eyes and hungry appetite down to Middleton's on Main and enjoy Celtic culinary creations freshly prepared and served with  verve. All your favorites are here, including corned beef and cabbage, fish fry and of course, shepherd's pie, featuring a hearty combo of beef, simmered in gravy with sautéed peas, root vegetables, onions and herbs, then topped with a mashed potato crust. Middleton's also hosts parties and offers catering. For something a bit less traditional, try the Irish Burrito, with house-made corned beef, beer-braised cabbage, red potatoes and creamy horseradish sauce in a jumbo flour tortilla. Have your party at Middleton's!!! Reservations accepted.

This deal is made available on Groupon by Local Flavor. Customers will receive a Local Flavor certificate, not a Groupon voucher. Groupon is not affiliated with or sponsored by MIDDLETON'S ON MAIN in connection with this deal.

This offer is not eligible for promo codes.

deals.pitchHtml:
Choose from Three Options

$16 for an American meal for two (up to $32 value)

  • Two burgers or sandwiches
  • Two orders of fries
  • Two beers

$30 for an American meal for four (up to $64 value)

$12 for brunch for two (up to $20 value)

  • Two brunch entrees 
  • Two coffees, teas, or soft drinks

Brunch takes place from 11 a.m to 3 p.m.

Three Things to Know About Hollandaise Sauce

Hollandaise gives velvety richness to several of the dishes on the menu. Read on to appreciate the hard work behind the smooth sauce.

1. Hollandaise is one of the five mother sauces in classic French cooking. The mother sauces—béchamel, espagnole, hollandaise, tomato, and velouté—are so named because they form the bases that other sauces are built upon. With a few added ingredients and steps, a hollandaise becomes the béarnaise for steaks or a clever way to hide jewels at the bottom of a bucket. On its own, however, it’s simply a combination of butter, egg yolks, and lemon or vinegar.

2. Despite its simplicity, it can give a new chef nightmares. Like a vinaigrette, hollandaise is an emulsion, which means it combines oil and water in a way they don’t naturally combine. But with a vinaigrette, you don’t have to worry about heat and timing. Add heat too fast and you start to scramble the egg yolks; add butter too fast and you risk a “broken,” or separated, sauce. A double-boiler is often recommended for control.

3. No one really knows how hollandaise it got its name. Some stories speak of the sauce being made for the king of the Netherlands during his visit to France as an imitation of a Dutch sauce. Others say it was named for the rich dairy products that made Holland famous and sparked an invasion of Belgian cats.

deals.pitchHtml:
Nothing brings friends and family together like pizza, and the stretchy melted cheese keeps you together since it refuses to snap. Celebrate your love of pizza and the eternal bonds it creates with this deal from Rosati's Pizza for $20 worth of Chicago-style pizzas, wings, sandwiches and more for just $10.

Rosati's serves up fantastic food made with quality ingredients in the tradition the family has known for generations. Go for big, beefy burgers, dogs, and hot Italian sandwiches like The Cheef with delicious Italian beef on Italian bread with mozzarella cheese melted on top. They offer authentic Chicago pizza using only the finest ingredients. Choose from traditional pizzas with the toppings of your choice, or one of their specialty pizzas with a unique combination of ingredients. Defeat your hunger with the Rosati's Monster Pizza piled high with gourmet Italian sausage, pepperoni, mushrooms, onions, green peppers, Canadian bacon, meatballs, black olives and green olives with sliced tomatoes and bacon on top!

deals.pitchHtml:
If it weren't for pizza, the pepperoni might have been reduced to a dark fate like topping eyelids in place of cucumbers in area spas, resulting in incredibly hungry spa-goers with sudden, inexplicable needs to sprinkle oregano. Naturally, the spicy meat met its doughy match instead and became the staple it is today. Taste this and plenty of other Italian and American favorites with this offer at Slice of Chicago, where you'll score $20 worth of fantastic foods for $10.

Now celebrating their 25th year, Slice of Chicago doesn't limit itself to just pizza, despite their moniker. No, the menu is rife with options including fully customizable pasta dishes with your choice of pasta, sauce and toppings. Too many decisions? Go for a pre-designed pasta specialty instead, like Cavatelli Agio or the classic but irresistible Lasagna. Wings, house-made soups and crisp salads coincidentally pair perfectly with a Cajun Chicken Sandwich or a 10-oz. Slice Burger made with Angus beef, by the way. Better load the car and come in soon, because that sound you're hearing is your stomach calling the shots.

This deal is made available on Groupon by Local Flavor. Customers will receive a Local Flavor certificate, not a Groupon voucher. Groupon is not affiliated with or sponsored by SLICE OF CHICAGO in connection with this deal.

deals.pitchHtml:
As Americans, we prefer things to be stuffed, like our bellies, our wallets, and our pizzas. Nancy’s Pizza® offers you the trifecta, because as the home of the original Chicago stuffed deep-dish pizza, they’ll fill you full of cheesy, saucy goodness without slicing away at your wallet. Try it for yourself with this deal where you get $20 worth of pizza, sandwiches and more for just $10.

Since 1971, when owners Rocco and Nancy Palese introduced stuffed pizza to Chicago, America has fallen in love with the vertically superior, cheesy, loaded deliciousness of Nancy’s deep-dish pies. Load yours up with your favorite ingredients, from Italian sausage to fresh basil and roasted garlic; or, go for specialty pies like their Northern Italian Veggie Pizza, with roasted red peppers, roasted garlic, black olives and fresh basil; or Rocco’s Party Pizza, with sausage, mushrooms, green peppers and sautéed onions. Nancy’s also offers “super thin” or traditional thin crust pizzas, still made with the same great ingredients as the deep dish and still amazingly good.

deals.finePrint: Limit 1 per person, may buy 1 additional as gift. Limit 1 per visit. Limit 1 per table. Valid only for option purchased. Dine-in only.
deals.highlightsHtml: BYOB eatery that has been around since 1979 serves up delicacies from its new menu, including muu ping pork skewers and duck noodle soup
deals.pitchHtml:
Choose Between Two Options

  • $11 for $20 worth of Thai food for two or more
  • $22 for $40 worth of Thai food for four or more
  • See the menu here.

Pad Thai: Stir-Fried Freedom

Pad thai packs in many of Thai cuisine’s characteristic flavors. To learn the other reason that it deserves its nationalistic name, read on:

Pad thai is such a staple of American Thai restaurants that many are simply named after the dish. In Thailand, the stir-fried meal—a mass of thin rice noodles intertwined with fried egg, tamarind, fish sauce, peanuts, and bean sprouts—is immensely popular, but it’s usually a street food; you’re more likely to find it wrapped in banana leaves and newspaper or Styrofoam than a top a tablecloth. Although its distinctive blend of sweet, salty, and sour flavors remains consistent, the dish can be customized by tossing in stir-fried meats or tofu and garnishing it with the heat of chili sauce or the clarifying pucker of lime. It’s a casual recipe that, with its lack of set proportions and endless flexibility, provides an expansive canvas for the noodle artist’s own sensibilities to shine.

Though its origins have been traced to southern China and Vietnam, pad thai is bound up in Thailand’s history to an extraordinary degree. After Prime Minister Plaek Pibulsonggram changed the country’s name from Siam to Thailand (or “land of the free”) in 1939, he strove to build up a national identity. Pad thai became part of his strategy. As Alexandra Greeley reported in Gastronomica, the government publicized the recipe to encourage the citizens of flood-prone lands to cook food that was both sanitary—cooked in clean, hot pans—and nutrient dense, with its fresh veggies, peanuts, and eggs. The ingredients themselves not only fueled Thailand’s agricultural economy, but also could be grown cheaply in home gardens. Pibulsonggram’s government also encouraged street vendors to cook and serve the dish in mobile carts, a tradition still enjoyed on the streets of Bangkok today.
